Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story: I stood behind the register, scanning items with practiced ease, when I saw my mother’s friend, Mrs. Lee, approach the counter. She smiled warmly, holding a sweater. “I need to return this, dear. I lost the receipt, but you know I shop here all the time.” My mind flashed to last week’s family dinner, where my parents reminded me how important it was to help our community and respect our elders—values I’d grown up with. But as a cashier, I was expected to follow the store’s strict return policy: no receipt, no return. My manager had warned us about making exceptions, and I knew there could be consequences if I didn’t follow the rules. Mrs. Lee’s hopeful eyes met mine, and I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. I could almost hear my mother’s voice urging me to be kind and helpful, but my manager’s words echoed just as loudly. I hesitated, caught between honoring my family’s expectations and fulfilling my responsibilities at work, unsure which path to take.
